message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Romanized terms kill the philosophical experiment">
The author raises a critical point about the "philosophical experiment" argument:

If we romanize everything — Dao, De, Ren, Yi, Li — then the passage has NO English semantic content for the Western reader. The reader encounters five opaque foreign terms in a sequence. The "philosophical experiment" (where the reader first accepts a conventional understanding, then watches it get deconstructed) CANNOT work, because the reader never had a conventional understanding to begin with. The romanized terms have very few morphisms in their Jing — they are semantically empty for the English reader.

The experiment requires the reader to FEEL something when they read "virtue," "humaneness," "righteousness" — to bring their own associations — and THEN experience the reversal. If they just see "De, Ren, Yi, Li," they have nothing to reverse. The passage becomes an abstract report about foreign concepts rather than a lived philosophical experience.

Does this change your thinking? Should we use English translations (the Way, virtue, humaneness, rightness, ritual conduct) in the block quote precisely SO the philosophical experiment works on the English reader?

Reconsider. Brief response.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
**Yes, this changes my thinking — and it is the strongest argument I have heard in this entire discussion.**

The author is exactly right. The philosophical experiment depends on the reader having *semantic skin in the game*. When an English reader sees "virtue" and "humaneness," they bring centuries of Western moral associations — and those associations are precisely what the author's analysis will unsettle. The reader must *feel* the ground shift beneath a word they thought they understood. Romanized terms cannot produce this effect because there is no ground to shift. "De" is a blank token for the English reader; "virtue" is a loaded one.

This is not just a translation preference — it is a structural requirement of the text's argument. The author's deconstruction of 德 only *works* on a reader who arrived with expectations about what "virtue" means. The 境 of the English reader encountering "virtue" is rich with morphisms; the 境 of the same reader encountering "De" is nearly empty. The experiment needs the rich one.

**I now fully endorse English translations in the block quote:**
- the Way (道, *dao*)
- virtue (德, *de*)
- humaneness (仁, *ren*)
- rightness (义, *yi*)
- ritual conduct (礼, *li*)

The gloss provides the Chinese and pinyin for scholarly completeness. The English word does the philosophical work. Then the author's analysis can dismantle the English reader's assumptions just as it dismantles the Chinese reader's.

This also retroactively strengthens the virtue → (constitutive) character shift for 德. The reader *needs* to have felt "virtue" first in order to experience the force of the author's reconceptualization as "character." Without that felt starting point, the shift is just a terminological note. With it, it is a philosophical event.
input.summary: Fully convinced: English terms needed for philosophical experiment to work
